H0.text: The umbilical cord supports a developing fetus by providing a protective barrier between the mother and the fetus.

H1.text: It keeps the fetus inside the mother until birth, which describes how the umbilical cord supports a developing fetus.

H2.text: It provides a navel when the baby is born, which describes how the umbilical cord supports a developing fetus.

H3.text: The umbilical cord supplies oxygen and nutrients to the fetus, thereby supporting the developing fetus.

A4.text: The umbilical cord does not directly connect to the mother's circulatory system, but instead joins the placenta, which transfers materials to and from the maternal blood without allowing direct mixing.

A5.text: The umbilical vein supplies the fetus with oxygenated, nutrient-rich blood from the placenta.

A6.text: The syncytiotrophoblast contributes to the barrier function of the placenta.

A7.text: The umbilical cord connects to the fetus by an umbilical cord of approximately 55–60 cm (22–24 inch) in length, which contains two umbilical arteries and one umbilical vein.
